column1: #Text=Server tuning — Nextcloud latest Administration Manual latest documentation
#Text=See Background jobs for a description and the
#Text=High system load will slow down Nextcloud and might also lead to other unwanted
#Text=To reduce load you should first identify the source of the problem.
#Text=Tools such as htop, iotop, netdata or
#Text=will help to identify the process or the drive that slows down your system.
#Text=you should make sure that you installed/assigned enough RAM.
#Text=If you run your database inside a VM, you should not
#Text=store it inside a VM image file.
#Text=Better put it on a dedicated block device to
#Text=reduce latency due to multiple abstraction layers.
#Text=Caching improves performance by storing data, code, and other objects in memory.
#Text=Memory cache configuration for the Nextcloud server must be installed and configured.
#Text=MySQL or MariaDB are preferred because of the performance limitations of
#Text=SQLite with highly concurrent applications, like Nextcloud.
#Text=See the section Database configuration for how to
#Text=If your installation is already running on
#Text=SQLite then it is possible to convert to MySQL or MariaDB using the steps provided
#Text=For more details and help tuning your database, check this article at MariaDB.
#Text=File locking is enabled by default, using the database locking backend.
#Text=places a significant load on your database.
#Text=configure Nextcloud to use Redis-based Transactional File Locking.
#Text=TLS (HTTPS) and file encryption/decryption can be offloaded to a processor’s
#Text=This can both speed up these operations while lowering
#Text=This requires a processor with the AES-NI instruction set.
#Text=Here are some examples how to check if your CPU / environment supports the
#Text=For each CPU core present: grep flags /proc/cpuinfo or as a summary for
#Text=all cores: grep -m 1 '^flags' /proc/cpuinfo If the result contains any
#Text=Search eg. on the Intel web if the processor used supports the extension
#Text=Intel Processor Feature Filter You may set a filter by
#Text="AES New Instructions" to get a reduced result set.
#Text=For versions of openssl >= 1.0.1, AES-NI does not work via an engine and
#Text=will not show up in the openssl engine command.
#Text=You can check the openssl version via openssl
#Text=If your processor supports AES-NI but it does not show up eg via grep or
#Text=coreinfo, it is maybe disabled in the BIOS.
#Text=If your environment runs virtualized, check the virtualization vendor for
#Text=HTTP/2 has huge speed improvements over HTTP with multiple request.
#Text=Most browsers already support HTTP/2 over TLS (HTTPS).
#Text=Refer to your web server manual for guides on how to enable HTTP/2.
#Text=If you are using a default installation of PHP-FPM you might have noticed
#Text=excessive load times on the web interface or even sync issues.
#Text=to the fact that each simultaneous request of an element is handled by a
#Text=So even on a small installation you should allow
#Text=more processes to run in parallel to handle the requests.
#Text=This link can help you calculate the good values for your system.
#Text=The OPcache improves the performance of PHP applications by caching precompiled bytecode.
